Posted By: Batstewart (11/5/2009 12:35:40 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Zinvampire, the simple explanation is: Creatures with flying *fly over* creatures without flying. So while the creature on the ground may have protection from the flyer, it is not able to reach to block it.  
  
*Protection* on a creature, protects that creature in many ways, but it does not protect the player from threats that evade said creature.  
  
If you read the rules for *flying* and for *protection*, you will see that they reflect that concept.
posts.html:
Zinvampire, the simple explanation is: Creatures with flying fly over creatures without flying. So while the creature on the ground may have protection from the flyer, it is not able to reach to block it.

Protection on a creature, protects that creature in many ways, but it does not protect the player from threats that evade said creature.

If you read the rules for flying and for protection, you will see that they reflect that concept.

posts.post_content:
So now win conditions cost ![White](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=W&type=symbol) and only $0.25
  
   
Did this yesterday in a casual game with my girfriend
  
T1:[Plains](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Plains), [Elite Vanguard](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Elite Vanguard)   
T2:Plains, [Veteran Armorsmith](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Veteran Armorsmith)   
T3:Plains, [Veteran Swordsmith](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Veteran Swordsmith)   
T4:Plains, Veteran Swordsmith, [Brave the elements](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Brave the elements) in response to her [Unsummon](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Unsummon), swing for 12 unblockable
  
T5:[Oust](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Oust) on her [Merfolk Sovereign](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Merfolk Sovereign), Brave the Elements, swing for 12 unblockable. I left one of my Swordsmiths untapped in case something happened and I didn't win.
  
   
It was a turn five win using only cards that costed ![2](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=2&type=symbol)![White](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=W&type=symbol), ![White](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=W&type=symbol)![White](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=W&type=symbol), ![White](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=W&type=symbol), and I only attacked twice.
  
This card is broken in my opinion. Protection from chosen color in general is broken in my opinion. It's why I love it, because most people don't realize it's awesomeness. Oh, play [Emerge Unscathed](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Emerge Unscathed) instead if you are only splashing white though.

posts.post_content:
Okay, so Blue is suffering pretty badly right now, and then WotC turns around and gives white a one-mana Negate, Overrun, and so much more. Why is white so powerful right now? Blue is supposed to have the best countermagic but everything good is WHITE for some reason. Also, I decided to play Standard so I wouldn't have to spend the $225 i will never have on tarmogoyfs, and then as if in response, WotC makes Baneslayer Angel. Why does this have to happen to this game that was once insufferably awesome and is now woefully imbalanced?  
  
Stupid recession.

Posted By: Th3_Dark_On3 (12/5/2009 1:50:34 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
@evenblackerlotus : If a creature has protection from something (let's say white), it means it can't be targeted, enchanted, equipped, damaged, or blocked by anything white. Unfortunately, [Day of Judgment](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Day of Judgment) does none of those five things, and so Brave the Elements won't save your guys.  
  
I know, it seems silly that Protection doesn't cover getting DESTROYED, which would seem to be the primary concern of being "protected"...but hey, that's what Wizards decided long ago. (Also, I just don't think it would feel right if a mere creature with protection from a color could live through the [Wrath of God](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wrath of God) or the [Day of Judgment](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Day of Judgment).)
posts.html:
@evenblackerlotus : If a creature has protection from something (let's say white), it means it can't be targeted, enchanted, equipped, damaged, or blocked by anything white. Unfortunately, Day of Judgment does none of those five things, and so Brave the Elements won't save your guys.

I know, it seems silly that Protection doesn't cover getting DESTROYED, which would seem to be the primary concern of being "protected"...but hey, that's what Wizards decided long ago. (Also, I just don't think it would feel right if a mere creature with protection from a color could live through the Wrath of God or the Day of Judgment.)

Posted By: ratchet1215 (9/30/2009 6:38:12 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Awesome card. But just to clear up some misunderstandings some posters here have:
  
1. This does squat against mass removal. Mass damage, yes, it works against, but mass removal, no.
  
2. [Wrath of God](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wrath of God) and [Infest](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Infest) do not deal damage. It is because they don't deal damage (and don't target, can't forget that) that this doesn't stop them. JaxonBateman, if those two did deal damage, protection would stop the damage. Protection prevents damage.
posts.html:
Awesome card. But just to clear up some misunderstandings some posters here have:
1. This does squat against mass removal. Mass damage, yes, it works against, but mass removal, no.
2. Wrath of God and Infest do not deal damage. It is because they don't deal damage (and don't target, can't forget that) that this doesn't stop them. JaxonBateman, if those two did deal damage, protection would stop the damage. Protection prevents damage.
Report Abuse  
Posted By: A3Kitsune (3/22/2010 3:38:05 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: It's this card's versatility that makes it insanely good. First, it's a one drop counter to removal or anything else that your opponent might do to one of your creatures. Second, it can turn a disadvantaged table into a huge advantage by giving one-sided damage prevention. Just block your opponents alpha strike and laugh. Last, it's white's one-drop [Overrun](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Overrun). Sure you don't get any bonuses to power or toughness, but you essentially get unblockable instead of that measly trample. The only problem is that the second two effects are sometimes imperfect against multi-color decks, which are obviously common in the meta. However, more often than not even against a multi-color deck most or all of your opponent's creatures share at least one color. Bottomline: this card wins games; early, mid, or late game. 5/5
posts.html:

Sure you don't get any bonuses to power or toughness, but you essentially get unblockable instead of that measly trample. The only problem is that the second two effects are sometimes imperfect against multi-color decks, which are obviously common in the meta. However, more often than not even against a multi-color deck most or all of your opponent's creatures share at least one color. Bottomline: this card wins games; early, mid, or late game. 5/5

posts.post_content: 1CMC should no have this huge effect, screw lightning bolt, giving all your creatures protection for 1 measly CMC, must be a misprint or some other kind of mistake, they cannot have playtested this at WotC and thought "this is a fair effect for 1CMC", unless it was the same guy that made gameslayer angel that made this. And it's uncommon, so they cannot even make the pathetic "mythic makes broken fair" argument with this one. Shame on you wizards. 1 CMC should never make your entire army nearly invulnerable and nearly unblockable. If this became the standard at 1CMC, then what would you get for 2CMC? All your creatures get first strike, flying and life link?
